Top tip for those who haven't seen - CanaryTokens: https://canarytokens.org/generate 

Generate files, drop them on your admin PCs, DMZ servers etc.  Generate executables, generate DNS entries, weblinks etc.  Leave them skattered around, document the codes and where they are.

Profit later.

1121797288605536257.text: It's a really easy mistake to make btw as when you look at something like Shodan, they appear as all kinds of weird and wonderful things - many home IPs now have IoT devices, consoles etc listening on random ports due to UPNP.

1121790583108857859.text: Emotet is not using IoT devices as C2 devices as reported. They’re Windows devices. It uses UPNP to open ports on routers behind NAT, so you’re seeing other ports with other services because UPNP.

1121783866363142145.text:
That one is a freebie btw, I couldn't find it documented anywhere online.

Running a SOC has been much more challenging than I imagined but every so often I see something which has hit banks etc - much higher budgets than us - and can legit go "We can detect that".

1121779429422829570.text: By the way, for monitoring for this - look for HTTP user agent "Windows_Installer" in proxy logs.  We do this, almost no false positives - rare that MSI files legit reach out to internet.pic.twitter.com/KgvS2ZnJwn

1120088337400967168.text: What do you need to be in InfoSec? Don’t take the online stuff too seriously (Twitter is largely nonsense), find a company that doesn’t suck and you can help, and get to work.

1120087391157587970.text:
InfoSec Twitter is a relative viewpoint bubble, you could read through tweets and think all we do is fly to conferences and live rock’n’roll lifestyles while being lavished by businesses as heroes. 

Spoiler: that fantasy isn’t real, it’s exclusionary, we’re exclusionary.

1120086299547971584.text:
To further complicate every business has different history and requirements, which different people may or may not fit into. And every business has different budgets. 

You could read Twitter and think whole InfoSec industry is 31337 ex-hackers popping custom shells. It isn’t.

1120085417540427776.text:
The secret to any good team is a selection of different people with different attributes - worker bees, free thinkers etc. 

Any good InfoSec department also has different roles - risk, learning etc - all of which have different skill requirements.

1120084599948890113.text:
If somebody is saying what you need to be in InfoSec industry they are usually wrong or looking at it from a specific angle (reality: InfoSec is a broadchurch). 

InfoSec also has a big diversity issue,  so those gates need opening.
